element_texts.text: [George M. Templeton and fellow soldier portrait]

Aug 14th 75 to Sept 10th unclear
+ heavy
Rain 14. 15. 19. 24. 25. 26. 27. 30 - 1.
18 - 9

Saturday Aug 14.75
camp 21
Broke camp 6 am Had to rely on myself for route - General course today North: I wished to clear Custers peak & swing around to the West between it & Terry - The route so far as surface is concerned is good - but the timber makes it utterly abominable - sometimes almost impassable

piled in inextricable confusion - on & across each other - However we worked away - cutting through dense woods. on bridging swamps & streams It has been the longest day of the trip to me & I am more tired than any day, simply because the march was so tedious & the long delays so constant - arrived at a stream which I presume to be Elk ck

Trout came out strong today as a road maker. He has a pioneer party of 20 men - who worked about every inch of the way. The pines were small & of very thick growth. - Where standing & green a regular lane had to be cut through them- When when down, & dead they were even more -  bring

Foote saw 2 elk - also a mountain lion - Bear sign very plenty - all in thick brush however - good camp, fine little stream, plenty of wood grass tolerable - 5 or 6 grouse bagged today - Ruff Rained on us a little & as I go to bed there is all appearances of a heavy rain: & raining now 9 pm - To bed early

at 4.10 - The wagons got in 4.45 - Camped & very glad to camp Nearly eleven hours on the road & made 9 miles - & a perfectly satisfactory distance considering the difficulties - Did not hunt but killed 3 deer might have killed more 12 deer killed today by the whole of us -

The route was much better than yesterday for several miles - but after that I was greatly troubled for the canons were very deep, & the timber very dense - Mounted a high bare hill to look, & came suddenly on 7 magnificent black tail Bucks - the very largest I have ever seen Fred saw them- before I did & called to me two or three times before I

camp 21
Sunday Aug 15. 75
Left the Comd in camp started 6.30 with Trout to look out a road - Found a good crossing of the divide, & sent Trout back to bring up the Comd-  While he was gone I killed two deer which I bagged, and another which escaped into a thicket -

the course - Had lunch & a drink, & put trout all right. Started up another high hill for a more detailed view & came upon a fine white tail Buck - which I killed & sent to the wagons - got an excellent route up the divide - & returned after a five mile trip to find Trout going all right but with a chronic disposition to keep to the eastward -

saw them & before I could get a shot they ran off - I fired at one running & I think hit him, but he got away into a dense thicket - I was disgusted for I ought to have gotten one at least - I then went back to the train, after taking a most satisfactory survey of the country & satisfying unclear of

we know but little as yet - The canons of this latter creek are terrific - I kept on a back bone which seemed to promise a comparatively easy descent - but it kept getting higher & higher - so that finally I determined to get down into a canon - I tried it but soon found myself stuck, could not get down unclear on horseback- Had to go back out the backbone The going down & back

& the East wall of the canon on my right was an almost perpendicular wall of limestone - showing that we are nearly out of the Granite - Kept well to the north west & got on top of a high divide, believe the waters on which we camped last night & crossed today - Elk Creek & another creek, of which

We had hardly got our tents pitched when it came on to rain - & is at it yet - regular Eastern pour down - Fred & I have traveled at least 30 miles up & down mountains & my horse is very tired - I feel first rate - killed a Ruff grouse on the Hill - shot its head off with rifle - my bag today 3 deer 1 grouse total bag of comd 10 deer two of them black tails - distance 8 miles

took time skill & work but Trout did admirably  - Night overtook us while yet on the divide so we had to go into camp - There is no grass & water can only be had by climbing down & up a steep & deep canon - However though we are now on "The mountain high in Heaven blue," I have had worse Compy

without very great labor - To crown all, I discovered that the Creek on which I had set my hopes, had no bottom land. I runs in a deep gorge with steep sides - & even had I got into it with my wagons there was no feed for my animals. After careful examination & with very great reluctance, I was forced to acknowledge myself beat & to give the order to turn back - The only parties

camp 22
Monday Aug 16, 75
Out early hunting road Set Trout to work at 6am to make what I had decided on last night as road - Went ahead several miles - & met the first decided disappointment of the trip - Tried every divide & with great difficulty got into the canon, but nowhere could I find a route practicable for wagons

is a cluster? from which diverge streams in all directions except west - On South, tributary of Rapid, on S. East Box Elder, On East Elk - & the yet unknown creek on which I am now encamped On N.E. are innumerable ravines tributary to I dont know what and on the North the deep canons of tributaries to Red Water take their rise - It is really little wonder that I could not get through, yet

who seemed to relish the order were the working parties &  I dont blame them - They have worked well & fruitfully & if the road could have been made they would have done it. The country is the most broken I have seen. The canons are most irregular. I feared it. The range of mountains culminating in Custer & Terry's peaks

getting to camp, I left the road, & before going a half mile, struck a pack of the herd of Black Tails that I saw yesterday - 

 There were 4, and though the nearest shot I had was over 200 yds, I bagged 3 of the finest that we have yet seen. The last shot at least 300 yds was one of my very best - I got the 3, in less than 5 minutes that is I killed them but

as "hope lives eternal" I would never have been satisfied with myself unless I had tried all I could to make "the riffle"-.

 My animals have had a hard time & luxuriated in the fine rich grass on which we are now encamped - I returned four or five miles on our yesterdays trail & camped on a small stream - tributary to What!! -  Just before

admiration of the whole camp - all the officers have been over to see them & they are really wagons? finest - Tonight I had them butchered & distributed to all who wanted (9 deer in 3 days) Only 4 miles today. Make camp here for some days, until Trout returns with the remainder of the Com'_ Mine the only deer bagged. Very foggy this morning. Rained nearly all night but beautiful today -

as only one fell in his tracks, I had hard work to find the other two - One went 300, the other at least 600 yds before falling & both were found dead. The last shot in shoulder from the front had 4 ribs broken, lungs perforated & hind leg badly hurt - yet was only accident that I got him - he went so far. My bag has been the

emboldened me to try to get still further north along my route which led to a retreat. I am much pleased with present prospects - Morton has got malaria & is not at all well  - Trout starts tomorro for Camp Crook to bring up the two cos - He is to make the trip there in one day & the return trip in two days. 

 Spent several hours today writing & got off some 15 pages of M. about finishing up the Red deer - Am very glad of it for it

camp 23 
Tuesday Aug 17, 75
Remained in Camp today to let every thing rest - We have a nice camp. I name it Camp Terry. Plenty of wood water & grass & all of the best - about 9 am Morton came in - He has been around Custer's peak & promises me a good route to Inyan Kara.  It was where I expected to go when I started from Rapid - but my success

Wednesday Aug 18, 75
Started 7 am with Morton & Joe to hunt up a road. Found a very good route between Custer & Terrys peaks, to the west of where I tried to go. About 7 miles out came across Jenney & his outfit - gave them directions how to get to camp & turned over to him a fine Buck that I had killed - after satisfying myself as to the route

rather bored me - I cant get up much enthusiasm on White Tails - but have got a fairly good article - 

  Only one deer killed today by old Erwin - Morton brought in three - but the companies complain already of the want of fresh meat , I will try & kill some tomorrow - as I go to hunt road - Copied at night & went to bed about 10. Ice in camp last night. Ther. on going to bed tonight 40°

difficulty - so I finally got mad & went back to the divide to find that Jenney had gone off too much to his right & was fast entangling himself & party in the same canons - went to the rescue at once & got them all out on my road, after the hours work - got 2 red deer - only saw 3 - There are very few in this vicinity - I think the Blk Tails have driven them off - Found Dr McGillicuddy & Foster in camp when I returned - They start tomorrow for Terry. Morton remains with me. Ice ¼ inch last night -

I started to return - went more to the South & East & became thoroughly convinced that to get through these hills is a matter of accident as well as knowledge - 

 Although but a short distance from the good route which I had found, I got completely entangled in a most abominable system of canons, through which I could get my horse only with the greatest labor &

the road is already made - Went over the ground on which I must make my road to Inyan Kara - & so far as I went, find it satisfactory - Then started off hunting & worked most faithfully for two hours before seeing anything - Then two deer jumped from a thicket & made off up a hill. I fired at them running & dropped one. It bawled loudly whereupon the other one stopped & tho I could see but a very small portion of him I fired. Foot & old Joe came up at this moment. Joe & I

Thursday Aug 19, 75
Morton went with Dr McG this time as he had many sights to verify - They started about 9.30 for Terry's Peak - but will be back for rations tomorro or next day - 

 I started out 9 am to look at a route that old Joe thinks is better than that of yesterday - It is better in grades but the old route has the very great advantage that about three miles of

Rained steadily from about noon until about 4 pm. Had my water proofs along & did not get wet - Took a nap in pm - Saw some ducks in a Beaver dam. They will soon be with us in abundance --- Saw a beaver. Bear signs very abundant but they remain hid in the thickets where we cannot see the animals themselves - Elk signs also plenty but no elk to be seen - 
pleasant evening around camp fire - To bed about 10.30

followed the trail of the second deer & I soon found him quite dead - My rifle is lovely. I very rarely miss - in fact I have not missed even a tolerable shot since I commenced hunting - Loading the deer on the horses, I sent Foote a head in hopes he might bag a deer. He got a fine shot but missed - We saw the other deer - It commenced to rain heavily, & we returned home - getting to camp about 1.30 pm - after a pleasant jaunt -

Morton Dr McG & party got into camp about 11 pm & stirred us all out of our slumbers, which was disgusting when we have to get up at daylight tomorro - wrote considerably today - on Antelope. Cant tell how it will compare with the other writing. To bed late -

camp 24
Friday Aug 20, 75
Did not go out today. Expected Trout & the Comd. which came in all safe about 10 am. Gave orders for the march tomorro

 Russell & Wissell? go with me - Issued rations to Comd. Borrowed 2 wagons of Jenney & sent them with one of mine back to last Camp for the ammunition which Trout had to leave -

came far ahead, & was enticed by the gamy appearance of the country into going into a canon up which my road is to run about a mile below where the road strikes it - 

 Saw no game & in crossing a bad bog covered with fallen timber all leading our horses. Ford's horse in a plunge forward struck him with his fore foot on the hip & hurt him quite seriously - so much

Saturday Aug 21, 1975.
Camp 25
A day of misfortune - up at daylight & got all the comd. off in good season under the guidance of old Joe. I went with Ford & the orderly on a hunt, & worked faithfully for some hours, seeing only the retreating flag of a fawn, as it scutted away in the thicket -

to the ambulance to see him. He was very cheerful & manly tho evidently badly hurt. We came on and camped at a spring I discovered 2 days ago - As soon as the tents were pitched the Dr undid the bandages which the Hospl Steward had put on Trouts ankle & we found that the poor fellows foot was terribly broken. The foot was turned completely sole up. The ligatures holding

so as to alarm me very considerably - after which however he got over it, & we mounted - we returned up the canon to where the road was to come & struck back hoping soon to find the wagons. Had to go clear back to the pond to meet them & found that Trout had been knocked down & nearly killed by a tree falling on him - went

It seems selfish to think of my loss in him, when he has such loss himself, but I had rather lost any six of my officers than him. He is so cheerful & manly under it, that he has won all our sympathies. I would not have had it occur for any money - He is the best officer in his place I ever knew - The accident has cast a gloom over the whole camp - Ford is all right tonight tho complaining a little - Distance 8 miles - Road fair, but heavy work -

the inner bone of the leg to its place in its socket were torn completely apart & the outer bone broken - Though the shin was not broken, the appearance of the leg made me sick & I had to leave - It appeared that if the shin were cut around the foot would drop off - He is laid up for six months & is possibly a cripple for life -

quaking asp & pine I came upon 8 splendid buck Elk - The thicket was so abominable that I could not get a sure shot though I was not more than 80 yards - aimed the very best I could & fired - the buck fell forward but recovered & walked away - I fired four shots, hit 4 times - put the bullets in one elk which went off bleeding very freely - I trailed him for a long

Sunday, Aug 22, 75
Camp No 26.
Started 6 am with wagons & pioneer party leaving the Co. in Camp - Foote acting unclear - & running the train - I went ahead hunting - In half an hour bagged a splendid buck - Went off on what I expected was the course, after a dilligent search through a dense thicket of

to find that the wagons had not come down it - struck up it looking for wagon trail but had to go clear back to where I had last seen it, to find that it had turned in directly the opposite direction from what I had understood Joe pushed on after & over took it at water about 12 m - Joe knows of no water further west, so I went into Camp. --- After resting an hour, I took another

time, but the ground was so tramped up by elk that I could not keep the right trail. To my thorough disgust failed to bag even one tho I know I mortally wounded 2 & hit three - gave it up & went on, as it was getting toward 10 am I thought I had best get back to the train. Turned towards the creek & after hard work pushing thru' thickets arrived at it

a short distance to enter right or left would have plunged us into Canons - Trout stood the march well & is quite cheerful - He shows great pluck and manliness - I forgot to say that we found no water on tomorro's march except a pond about 2 miles ahead - we may have a dry camp - Distance today 7 miles - saw ducks, grouse & Sand Hill Cranes today -

horse & started with Joe to look out our route for tomorrow - Went out at least 6 miles - The big Canon Morton's? is very near us on the west. We hunted a road to it, & tomorro will take up it - The route is good, & work very little. Our route today has been a marvel of engineering & Joe deserves great credit for working it out so well.

Big Canon - Mortons - Turned up this - about 3 miles up came to forks - old Joe was bent on taking the left hand branch - I equally on the right - as the canons were taking me too far south - all the time - Just at the forks found water in a little side spring. The fork followed looked unfavorable at first but soon widened out into a great bottom. Two miles brought us to a broad meadow like

Monday, Aug 23d, 1875
Camp No 27
Broke camp 6 am. Our trail led too much to the south, but there was no help for it, as the hills & canons were inexorable - We followed down a branch of Rapid for some 4 miles, then turned up another branch to its head, crossed a divide followed a course down & in something near 2 miles came into the

were rewarded, by ?debarking? on to the Red Water just at the mouth of Custer's "flood? valley" - Just below were most lovely springs, & as I was afraid of tiring Trout I camped - The road has been very crooked but excellent distance 15½ miles --- We are all elated at crossing the country so successfully - Bagged 2 deer this am, within a mile of Camp & before I had half finished my first pipe - Excellent camp - We are very near our camp of 10 June

expanse, the main stream of which led too much to the north for me - I noticed a little depression to the west, & pushing through a belt of woods came to another meadow like expanse which as we went down rapidly narrowed with a very crooked canon, which every moment looked as if it would shut in on us - We persevered however &

mostly on the same course we came down making a V three miles in each of the legs & only one mile across the spring - Had some trouble with old Joe. He would not do as I wished. Had his own ideas of the country & was determined to carry them out though without insubordination or disrespect - I however am as obstinate as he - though when I stopped to lunch, he came near getting the train entirely off the course I wanted it to go - arrived in time: tho not soon enough to save a good deal of work for the men. Gave him a good blowing up, &

Tuesday Aug 24, 74
Camp 28
Broke camp 7.30 am. as we were to have so short a march - In one mile & a half we made our old camp of June 10 - "Floral Valley", where we had the snow storm - came over the ridge & went down to Indian Spring - 7 miles - Found the water very alkaline & the grass dried up & determined to push on in search of some thing better - went back

is already autumn here _ I walked out a mile or so, with my rifle - Except the quaking asp. the flora is very much like western N.C. on a small scale - Flowers are in very great profusion - Huckleberries are rife, but they are small scrubby things hardly worth picking - I saw also some holly, the first I have seen in the Hills, & many very familiar plants whose names even I dont know - Shot a deer during the walk but could not find him. Returned to camp; got the Hdqr Sergt & his dog to go with me & we found him quite dead.

it evidently did him a power of good - as he has been very apologetic & conciliatory in his manner ever since - Took the guidance into my own hand, & brought the comd. onto a fine rolling prarie & about 2½ pm found a small stream of water & encamped.  It is probably the most elevated camp we have made in the Hills - I do not know how high - but the trees & bushes begin to show the "sear & yellow leaf" - It

last page repeated
Trout stood the march splendidly - & is very cheerful. Just at dark we were all electrified by the report that a mail had come. It was soon brought down & opened in my tent & was apparently very satisfactory to all. To me very much so except that there is a prospect of my losing Morton, whose wife is about to be confined - He has permission to go in - Letters from Father & several to Ford from Gracie  Ma? P & others - Tooty had arrived

Trout stood the march splendidly - & is very cheerful. Just at dark we were all electrified by the report that a mail had come. It was soon brought down & opened in my tent & was apparently very satisfactory to all. To me very much so except that there is a prospect of my losing Morton, whose wife is about to be confined - He has permission to go in - Letters from Father & several to Ford from Gracie  Ma? P & others - Tooty had arrived

last page repeated
Wednesday Aug 25, 75
Camp 29
Three months today since we left Fort Laramie - Broke camp 7 am. Followed down the creek for about 2 miles then across a high open prairie. Soon the ravines began to encroach on us, & we were forced to cross some quite deep ones. Two or three had water. The whole country is of the Red bed & gypsum

Wednesday Aug 25, 75
Camp 29
Three months today since we left Fort Laramie - Broke camp 7 am. Followed down the creek for about 2 miles then across a high open prairie. Soon the ravines began to encroach on us, & we were forced to cross some quite deep ones. Two or three had water. The whole country is of the Red bed & gypsum

last page repeated
11 am - very pretty camp though wood is scarce & water poor - It is however as good as I dared hope - Ordered the teams back to bring up Hawley & Comd. wrote him a long letter of instructions - It will require two trips to get him up. He is to be at Indian Spring with his whole comd. on 2d Sept. Wrote to Pollock. Issued an order relieving Lt Hall & Compy from

11 am - very pretty camp though wood is scarce & water poor - It is however as good as I dared hope - Ordered the teams back to bring up Hawley & Comd. wrote him a long letter of instructions - It will require two trips to get him up. He is to be at Indian Spring with his whole comd. on 2d Sept. Wrote to Pollock. Issued an order relieving Lt Hall & Compy from

some life into me & I
got it out pretty quick. Took a pot shot on a part of the covey & bagged 4, & 1, as they rose - making 5. As they are large fine birds, this was very good - They flew to an immense distance & I saw no more of them - Foster starts out tomorrow on a surveying expn. down this creek of which we know nothing - If it is Bear Lodge I wish to go down it - Have offered Pollock 50 beefer cattle. Distance today 9 miles - Fish in this stream -

Today, & could certainly have bagged one or more but that I dared not leave the comd. for I was anxious to go just in a certain way, & could not trust anyone to take the lead. At a swale circle saw several small unclear but was too lazy to get out my shot gun. A fine large flock of sage hens, put some life into me, & I

one side as I pulled
trigger - my bullet was dodged & I missed a deer - I was sure of it - "There's many a step" - Saw 3 deer but had no other chance - One of the men bagged a magnificent Black Tail today. The Dr. got some fish - dace - Had our sage hens roasted for dinner They were delicious - Corpl came in bringing note rom Jenney - He has lost my pack mule - D--- him. Heavy shower in afternoon with sharp thunder & lightning - Went to bed in good season. Foster & old Joe left this am for a survey of Inyan Kana & Bear Lodge Creeks --

Thursday Aug 26, 75
N. 30 Camp Bradley
Train started very early this am for Terry - also a det.l of a N.C. off & 4 men for Pollock. After breakfast started out in a reconnaissance with Foote, which we soon converted into a hunt. Startled a deer & got within 30 yds & was taking sight when another deer suddenly sprung to one side, startling mine which made a motion to one side just as I pulled

additional 100 pages. My book grows wonderfully, but I fear I have not time to complete the 2 volumes by the middle of Decr. at which time I want to go east to arrange for the publication - Have not been out of Camp today scarcely out of my tent - Trout doing splendidly - He does not want to go in - shall remain out if he wishes - Driven to bed early by the cold -

Friday Aug 27 - 75
_____ _____ ______
Heavy rain at intervals  all night - got up late - the day cold raw & with occasional showers, some times heavy. Devoted the day to writing & did remarkably well. Finished the game animals of the plains having complete 234 pages of No 3 in these alone - Will now go to work on the game birds which will probably give me an

went after them on the 
principle that a duck in hand is worth a deer in the mountain to a hungry man - Shot very well & knocked down 16 ducks & a heron, but because I had no dog I only brought in 9 of the ducks. Left them lying in plain view in beaver dams - of course the beavers having dammed everything there was no necessity for my doing it - Had a very long ride, saw plenty of signs of Elk & deer, but not

Saturday Aug 28, 75
Had to go hunting today. Was a case of "groundhog: "our Mess" was by the neglect or economy of Hubert run out of all meat but ham No bacon, no venison & the beef herd yet a long way off - I started about 9 am determined to bag something, going up the creek I found ducks & went after them on the

future? programme for our march, which is fortunate, as I had fixed it any way - 

 Got a good view of the Big Horn mountains today. They are entirely covered with snow. Huge masses of white from summit to plains line. An expedition there will have to hurry up its work - Snowed up 28 Aug. Has been quite cold & windy today. This Inyan Kara Country is simply a slice of the plains sandwiched between mountain ranges - The climate in places is  bad - To bed early, very tired -

a single animal. Where they have gone to is impossible to say. Got back about 4 pm after a very hard and unsatisfactory days work, to find that Jenney had got into camp with his party. He started down Red Water but saw so many Indian signs that he determined to get back to the protection of greater numbers - He agrees with me in my
Newton–Jenney Party of 1875, led by Henry Newton and Walter P. Jenney, and escorted by a military detachment

to get 9 - 3 mallard & 6 
teal - lost one of each - saw them fall but could not find them - Oh! for  Buckskin Retirement early, & with the Dr's assistance loaded nearly 200 cartridges, so am set up for a little while - gave all necessary orders for the move tomorro - Jenney & Foote went on top of Inyan Kara - Found Custer's name deeply cut in the rock on the very top. Had to punish a man today for the first time since I have been out - sitting down & reading on post -

Sunday, Aug 29, 75
Up at usual time. A doubtful kind of day, might be good or very bad, so though fresh meat is an absolute necessity, I dared not risk a long tramp after deer but about 10 am went up the creek for more ducks. Fred went out, though he had one of his bad Paulsing head aches - Ducks were few & far between, but managed to get 9 - 3 mallard & 6

Monday Aug 30, 75 - 
Camp 31.
Started from Camp at 8.30. The wagons got off an hour later - Went up the creek but got no ducks - struck off to the east, to find out something about the country - It is a curious one - Following up one of the miserable little dry arroyos that are tributary to the Inyan Kara, one first comes to huge & deep canons. These passed to beautiful

while at dinner we were visited with a sharp wind which came near demolishing the camp. Tore up the Hospl tent & destroyed some of the property. Wrote at night about eight more pages in "game".  Dont like its connection into preceding but cant do all artistically when am in camp -- 

  Fred all right tonight --
  Must to bed quite late --

crossed Custers trail well? up on the divide, passed for miles through one of the most lovely hunting countries I ever saw, without finding anything whatever - It was a dead country, & but for an occasional snow bird lifeless - coming back to camp in disgust, Cook the orderly called to me & pointed - Dismounting I went in front of him & looking in the direction of his finger, saw

valleys, more or less wide & with side hills varying from a bare slope to 2 or 300 feet - Hundreds of these valleys go to make up the miserable little stream of Inyan Kara. In all my experience I have known of no more beautiful country nor a more bountiful provision of lovely valleys rich in grass, going to

last page repeated
through the thicket 200 yards away, a splendid Buck. I could get no nest from which I could see him, so after careful aim fired offhand & missed. The deer did not move, putting in another cartridge I was getting ready to fire when he started directly away from me - Determined not to lose my only chance, I took quick sight & fired & was

through the thicket 200 yards away, a splendid Buck. I could get no nest from which I could see him, so after careful aim fired offhand & missed. The deer did not move, putting in another cartridge I was getting ready to fire when he started directly away from me - Determined not to lose my only chance, I took quick sight & fired & was

last page repeated
was about 130 yds from me & going like the wind but directly from, & considerably below me I fired -- He ran a hundred or so yards & fell dead. The bullet struck him in the middle of his belly & came out in the neck. He was just lighting on his fore legs after a bound & my bullet passed between his hind legs - Lt Foote said the shot

was about 130 yds from me & going like the wind but directly from, & considerably below me I fired -- He ran a hundred or so yards & fell dead. The bullet struck him in the middle of his belly & came out in the neck. He was just lighting on his fore legs after a bound & my bullet passed between his hind legs - Lt Foote said the shot

Tuesday Aug st. 75

    No 32.

______    ______   ______
Sent out corpl & man to bring Hawley to move camp.

 After breakfast started with Fred & Foote out to look for a camp. Came across ridges northerly to a large valley. Followed it up to water & good grass. Then going up a lateral ravine struck my road in Foote canon -- sent orderly back to bring up comd & camp it in the proper place & went on after Hawley. Found that Sergt Davis did not make any cut off as I directed but went all the way round by Indian spring

sportsman - It isn't in him. He has very little taste that way - He gets awfully tired following me about & I had to scold him a little tonight for being discontented - It is doing him good - & whether it did or not he is in for it now - My camp is the same as 29. Brought Jenney with me. To bed 10.30

struck a fresh trail of wagons on my road going to Indian Sps & soon after overtook a man who turned out to be a messenger to the Herald Cor unclear. He had come up with Lt Kingsbury from Capt Pollocks Comd with Hall's wagons after rations. We camped at Indian Sps & remain there tho my orderly told him we were camped at this place -- The Corpl & man were found & taken up to the divide with orders to bring Capt H down the valley to their camp. We then started for Camp. Before very

struck a fresh trail of wagons on my road going to Indian Sps & soon after overtook a man who turned out to be a messenger to the Herald Cor unclear He had come up with Lt Kingsbury from Capt Pollocks Comd with Halls wagon after rations. We camped at Indian Sps & remain there tho my orderly told him we were camped at this place -- The Corpl & man were found & taken up to the divide with orders to bring Capt H down the valley to their camp. We then started for Camp. Before very

Wednesday Sept 1,1875
______ cp 32 __________
started out about 9 am to hunt up Burt & the train.

  Foote with me. After a long ride we found them a mile below Cold Spring, in Camp & very comfortable . 
  We had a pleasant visit got a mail. -   tho not a letter for me from any "home bodies". 
  A long & gossippy letter from Col Gantt - & a shorter note from Genl Bradley. He sends lots of papers

wagons came up late 4.30 We have a very nice camp for our transfer. Good water & grass. Open valley with heavy pine woods on each side - Had good nap in afternoon & a splendid saddle of venison for dinner. Davenport wanted escort to take him in - Could'nt see it. He goes to Red Cloud Agency, to the Indian Council.  Jenney over at Hdqrs & we had a pleasant unclear - To bed about 10.30 pm -

last page repeated
Blackmore was to arrive in N.Y. by 15 ult? & thought he could reach Ft Laramie by 20th, but had not arrived when Burt left - I still have hope that he may join me within a few days - If so I will take him back to Rapid & have a gelorious? hunt - 

 Killed two wolves today. The first a coyote, I butchered. The first shot hit him in the fore leg & while

Blackmore was to arrive in N.Y. by 15 ult? & thought he could reach Ft Laramie by 20th, but had not arrived when Burt left - I still have hope that he may join me within a few days - If so I will take him back to Rapid & have a gelorious? hunt - 

 Killed two wolves today. The first a coyote, I butchered. The first shot hit him in the fore leg & while

severed with lightning. It was torn to fragments - Found Andrews & in camp - Letter from Pollock as broad in cheek? as himself - Morton's wife has had the baby & is doing well. So I will not lose him - Saw a small herd of antelope today far off - They had been frightened by Jenney's party - & were running away - saw no deer - Had no time to hunt - Rode at least 25 miles today - & am tired - Andrews & others at my tent tonight - Jolly time - To bed late -

try harder to get away. The next was a large buffalo, or prairie wolf. He was about 150 yards off & running across me, & I knocked him at the first shot. After leaving Burt Camp we had a heavy thunder storm with considerable rain - but had our water proofs - Just after the worst was over passed a large pine which had just been

Thursday Sep 2d. 75.
Camp 32
An eventful day. Burt arrived with the supply train - Lawson & Whitman accompanying him - Soon after King came in with the two Cos. from Terry, & except Russell & Wessels, we are all united again - Trout is a wonderful fellow - On the arrival of the train he took to his crutches - hobbled to an ambulance, was driven down & himself
Reference is to Brig. General Alfred E. Terry

about the death of Frank Blair, but on all sort of gossippy subjects. It may be fancy, but I think I write to him better than any one else - Wrote also to Father & Mother & to Tooty - scolding her a little for not getting treatment - Have not been out of camp today & my rifle is getting rusty - We received all sorts of nice things by the train & I made such a dinner

Friday Sepr 3d. 75
Camp 32
Soon after breakfast The Herald man Davenport came to bid me "good by". He is off for the Indian Council, near Red Cloud. Shortly after Burt (whom I authorized to go to the Council came to do likewise also Kingsbury - By 9 o'ck all these were gone, & about 12 Whitman & Dr Sam started in the other direction for

Sunday Sept 5th
Munson? & the 2 Inf'y Cos started on the return trip. Morton made application to go in, & I let him, tho I did not want to. Deacon Willard the Trader packed up & left. The comd. is so sober, he is nearly broke -- McMillan the Inter unclear, man went also. So we are nearly out of reporters? -

Saturday Sepr. 4th 75
Jenney & his party started about 10 am. Coles & his Compy went with him. Have only 2 available Cos. & they are very small. King shot a fine buck Elk today quite near camp. Wrote letters, took a hot bath, had my hair cut read newspapers & loafed generally -

sent in my arty & all the surplus amn. by Munson. About 9 am Foote & I started with 2 wagons - part of Hd qr guard & a Sergt & 10 men on a hunting expedition - & are now encamped at Joes Spring 23½ miles from Camp. Transfer on The Terry road. Nothing seen yet. Tomorrow we go on to Rapid Ck some 5 or six miles East in a direct line - about 10 by the road - I send
The Terry Road was named for General Alfred Terry just as the Custer Trail was named for George Armstrong Custer

fire killed-
unclear we pushed along & about 8 a big buck got up on a hill side & ran into a thicket - He stopped about 200 yds off & though I could see but a small portion of him I fired. He went off. I put in another cartridge. The hill was so steep that he could not run fast, but to counterbalance the brush was so thick that I could only get occasional glimpses of him but I determined to give him one more - & taking good

Monday Sepr 6, 75
Foot & I left Camp at 6:30 am giving directions to the Sergt to move camp to a fine spring 7 or 8 miles East. Sent Joe to look for the mule lost by Jenney - We hunted through a lovely country for game.  But in a couple of miles the canon which we were following became very steep deep & crooked & the timber all

aim fired. The deer disappeared but the bushes were so shaken that I was sure I had knocked him down & sent a man up, who found him quite dead. Shot quarterlingly? but through the heart. This was a very remarkable shot. The distance was at least 350 yds. Yet I took exactly the same sight that I would at 35 yds. Foote said today, "I begin to have a superstition about that

going on the creek we were on ran onto another & a few moments after we found ourselves on Custer's trail - Coming north on Rapid - Coming up the stream we soon found ourselves at my Elk ground of 22 ult. Foot & I separated & went through. Naturally I worked to the spot where I had shot the 3, Aug 22, & on arriving near, ran onto the carcass of one which however had of course become food for

got them to the wagons. It is an awful thicket. Sent a couple of men & pack mule to camp. Bagged another nice buck & as the day was very warm came to camp - getting in about 2 pm - Foote had arrived an hour before Joe did not find the mule. It is undoubtedly dead - Nice camp at a most glorious spring. Tomorrow we try again for Elk - To bed 9.30 pm

Wednesday Sept 8, 75
Got out by 6 am today determined to have a good hunt, and a good hunt we have had with little result - Went north after black tails & Elk - Bagged 1 B.T. quite early & had a long shot at a large B.T. back & think I hit him but he got away - Went down the big Canon, turned up a side unclear canon & came

The country is very broken & covered with dense thickets so that it is almost impossible to get at the game - Horseback hunting is too noisy & the stoutest man would soon tire out on foot. Nolan gave us a serenade tonight. The first he have had in the hills. Move back tomorro. Bear & Elk sign very plenty - The animals cannot be found

to camp through a lovely hunting country, without seeing a thing (except a fox which I shot), simply because we had the wind in our backs. Found where several Elk had been scratching & pawing & our approach had undoubtedly driven them to cover - We have been very unlucky on this hunt in the wind - start whatever direction we may,  the wind is sure unclear to be flawy, or to go directly against our success. Camped at side hill spring -

Thursday Sept 9th 1875
Commenced raining about 10:30 last night & kept at it all night. Had breakfast put. & the winds? turned out. By 6:30 am it had ceased & we got up & had bkfst, but the mist covered every thing - so that we could see nothing - & the bushes were so wet that hunting

& misted all day, so we did not hunt. Have not fired my gun today - nor seen anything but a hawk to fire at - Found all right in camp - Fred well & has enjoyed himself. Trout getting on splendidly & all glad to see me - Had a nice camp fire & enjoyed it - Went to bed about 9 pm after giving orders for a short move tomorrow

later King came in with 2 deer - & 6 Ruff grouse. Had a good nap & wrote some - but unsatisfactorily -Joe returned just at dark with information that no water is to be found on my proposed route - so I am forced to go for some distance tomorrow on Custers trail. High wind last night & this am. Lovely night. One of my prettiest camps

plenty - We must kill some soon - They are getting careless -
Pine in this section quite poor 
Black Hills favourite place for migratory birds to stop - Numerous here in Sept that do not breed here )Sepr 8)

Elk Shaking over by 31 Aug -
The first red deer found out of velvet bagged Sepr 6th
No Elk here about where I shot the 3 since - very shy -
Begin to get in droves by Sepr 1. Each sex by itself -
Sepr 7. A buck & doe Elk found together for the first time this season. The buck also whistled - which is a symptom of running? - It will commence very soon -
Deer grow a substance called velvet on their antlers that they shed during early September
"running" was probably meant to be "rutting"/breeding season




Elk shaking over by 31 Aug.
The first red deer found out of velvet bagged Sept 6th
--No Elk here about where I shot the 3 since - very shy -
--Begin to get in droves by Sept 1. Each sex by itself ---
______
Sept 7 - A buck & doe Elk found together for the first time this season. The buck also whistled - which is a symptom of rumming? - It will commence very soon --

to have the making of my own maps. St Bouche being also in Omaha all the Officers who have, altho with one, in the surveys will be on hand, & I do not fear other than a good result -- The miners went out in excellent humor & were much gratified at your courteous & considerate treatment. Had however you not most fortunately met Capt Benteen there would have been great trouble perhaps bloodshed. 

 They were greatly incensed against him for more unclear & threats alleged to

fine climate & occupation of mind that his daily outing give him-- I would like extremely to have my maps of the Black Hills made up under my own supervision. If therefore there is no objection to the plan I would be very greatly obliged if St Morton & Foster both of 3d Cavy be ordered to report to me at Omaha on the completion of this expeditions 

  The Engineer Dept may make (or would if they knew of it) some objection to this but as I am responsible I ought

was struck by a falling ice? & had a bone of his leg broken.  This occurred on 21 ult.? .  He has earned? the most cheerful & plucky spirit since the accident & attends now to all his duties as usual. 

 He did not wish to leave the expdn The Dr did not recommend it the air & climate evidently having the most beneficial affect -- so I do not send him in. To a man of his disposition nothing would be so trying as inaction, & I think he has the best chance for

the expedn. is ordered to report to Capt Pollock - I have issued rations to that Co to the 10th Oct, and also gave Capt P 10 beef cattle. My Comd. being now supplied with all necessary for the time that I propose to be out I have relieved the 2 Infy Cos & ordered them to report to Col Bradley. 
I am truly sorry to have to report that Lieut Trout

over to the unclear meeting on 10th. I took with me 2 Cos Cavy one of which I left there with instructions to report to Capt P. on his arrival -

  Finding that the work of the Expedn took me entirely away from the vicinity of Capt P. & that it would be almost impossible to act with him I believed that your wishes would be best carried out by returning one of my cos permanently. Comp I unclear

words cut off the page was therefore

The other with the Hd qrs will move allong the N.E. & E base of the Hills joining the inside work with the streams outside - Mr Jenney desires to return through the "bone fields" & I expect to strike from the mouth of Rapid to about the mouth of porcupine ck on White River & return to Ft Laramie by way of that river and the agencies. You requested me to give Capt Pollock all the assistance in my power. When I went

the Crow Peak Mountains. One of my parties has already reached the Belle Fourche surveying Inyan Kara and Bear Lodge Creeks - I have designated the 20th Sepr, on which day all the parties are to concentrate near Bear Butte on the N.E. of the Hills - I anticipate that the work in the Hills proper will be done by that time. If not it will be finished very soon after. One party will then run down the Belle Fourche to its junction with the south sheyenne

The supply train arrived on 2d. & I am now unloading & preparing for our final round before finishing our work - I have kept 2 parties of surveyors under Lts Morton & Foster in the lined out: 3d Cavy field all the time, & have materials by which we can make as perfect a map as can be made without surveyors company & chain - I am very sure that no part of the wilderness is as well known as the Black Hills now are. My route from here will be to the N.E. along the base of

Camp transfer
10 miles fr. Inyan Kara 
Sepr 4. 75
Genl Geo. Crook
Recd. Since my last letter this comd. has worked its way slowly northward until N.E of Terry's peak where we found the country impassable for wagons. I then turned to the westward passing between Terry & Custers peaks & keeping S.W. along a huge divide the only practicable route struck our entering trail at our camp of June 11 - Thence I marched N.W. to Inyan Kara where my camp now is.

drawn map of Terry's and Custer's Peaks with trails and camp
drawn map of Transfer Valley, Ind. Sp., Corner Ck, Cold sp., Burt's sp.

1- Cold Spring - fine cool & abundant in June, now perfectly dry- An arroyo a mile south, dry in June, now a nice running stream - Burt is camped on it. Jenney saw great abundance of gooseberries on Mountains near Cold Spring - saw several grouse, & Lewis & Clark's wood pecker but did not have my shot gun -

31-
Great variety of birds about Inyan Kara, many of them entirely new to me. Wished for a "Baird & Cassin". - The heads of Inyan Kara Creek are splendid large valleys - & that they so "peter out", & result in so insignificant a stream would be remarkable in any but a limestone, gypsum red-bed formation -

30 -Tributaries of Inyan Kara ck very remarkable in length numbers & lovely valleys towards their heads - Jenney & Foot ascended the Inyan Kara Mt yesterday. Country about here in valleys covered with Hop vines - the very finest I have ever seen wild & Foote says No 1 hops even cultivated -
drawn map of Camp Bradley, camp 30, Red Water

Trout wants to continue the trip - Plucky but indiscreet - He may do so if he wishes.
28 - Mallard, shovel bills & teal quite plenty. The first breeds here - The others just arrived from the north - I hear plover every night & tonight heard a regular Jack or English snipe - yellowlegs, sandpipers &c are coming on rapidly - Saw Big Horn Mountains are completely covered with snow - this 28 aug?

Called "Camp Bradley" splendid Hop region - as fine wild as I ever saw cultivated. Fish in stream - wood plenty but rather far off - grass good - Fair camp - The country is really a strip of the plains inserted between high mountain ranges -
- 26. Fine spring in Mts 2 1/2 miles east - Country very broken & cut up by gullies in the red beds. Looks like a huge N.C? old field - Grass very fine

Hills - The heads of Rapid ck are a succession of Beaver dams, which are the resort & breeding places of numerous water foul - shot 3 Elk bagged none - Rather disgusted but if I had killed them I could not have got them to camp.
25. Camped under Inyan Kara water alkaline - all the maps erroneous - Sage Hens today for the first - Country bare of timber - soil red beds & gypsum -

21. Trout broke his leg - Ford hurt by his horse - Miriads of blue bottle flies & insects of all kinds - Camped near top of divide between Terry & Custer peaks. Several hundred feet above camp Terry - Course N.N.W
22. Saw sand hill cranes young ones large enough to fly. They pair - saw several broods of Mallards. Nearly grown - & a flock of 4 Teal the first I have seen in this

which curious as it may appear, has had no effect on the flowers & shrubs -
19. Another barren doe today. Bear & Elk signs abundant. The animals themselves hid in the thickets - Elks capacity for hiding very wonderful for so large a beast - Two remarkable shots today - The first at a deer running, 100 yds, dropped her in her tracks - The other 120 yds could only see part of its flank - Bullet went in at lowest rib out at shoulder, same side.

16. Two of the Bk Tails bagged today covered with long coarse reddish hair very thinly set. The third had shed his coat, & was covered with a short thick coat of mouse coloured hair. He was not the largest or fattest, was the oldest & was getting his winter coat early -
Night of 17th ice ⅛ inch
"        "   18    "    ¼ inch

14
On Box Elder & Elk Cks the deer are very plenty but very small - A very great number of barren does - Sand hill cranes
on Elk -
15. Came on 2 Sand hill cranes feeding on side of a mountain - no shot - Fred's orderly saw an animal which from description must be a Lynx --
another barren doe today

Animals
Bear - several species - Elk - Black Tails, Red deer, ground hog, Wolves, Foxes, Red pine squirrel - very small chipmunk or ground squirrel, Lynx - cougar or Mt Lion - mouse - Buffalo

Birds
Kingfisher, yellow bird, Sage Hens, Buzzard, Heron, Teal,  Shovel bill (Migrating birds)

Reptiles
Rattle snakes, garter snakes, water mockasin, Bull frog, striped head turtle, saurians
